channel.title: Experiences on Matthew do Santos-Zounon
channel.description: Recent content in Experiences on Matthew do Santos-Zounon

item.title: DeepLearning is expensive. Can we classify users using standard data science methods?
item.description:
Abstract

This report explores whether small groups of Reddit users can be accurately classified using only simple, non-aggregated features from the Reddit Comment Corpus. We engineer new features, including sentiment and NSFW scores, to improve classification. Using a Random Forest model, we test performance on several user groups but find precision and recall to be below 25%. Our results suggest that more complex methods are likely required to achieve high accuracy classification.

item.title: Hacking Firmware for Fun and Profit
item.description: My first phone had been jailbroken, ran multiple OS’s and had a few hardware swaps; that phone was defintely mine. My current phone came preinstalled with Facebook and YouTube and there is no way to uninstall them. And my laptop asks if I want to update now or try again tomorrow; that’s not my laptop anymore - microsoft owns it. If I can’t modify my computers, they are no longer mine. In this blog post I walk through how anyone can read and modify the firmware in their device to regain ownership. Read More

item.title: Improving Parabix Performance on ARM Architecture
item.description:
Abstract

This report details our efforts to improve the performance of Parabix, a parallel bitstream framework, on ARM architecture. Parabix leverages Single Instruction, Multiple Data (SIMD) parallel processing to achieve gigabit per second text processing. While Parabix has proven its efficiency on x86 architecture, it did not achieve an equivalent performance on ARM due to the need for architecture-specific optimization required to take full leverage the different SIMD instruction set. In this project we utilize ARM’s advanced SIMD extension, NEON, to improve the performance of Parabix on ARM.

item.title: Dev Tooling & Leadership @ Rivian|VW
item.description:
Role: Software Integration Engineer
Company: Rivian & Rivian and Volkswagen Group Technologies
Location: Vancouver, BC

Overview

Owned the release execution for v2.21 while scaling automated UI and API coverage across Android and iOS. The goal was to keep the release cadence predictable, reduce manual testing, and keep QA aligned with product and engineering.

What I shipped

  • Led a sub-team of four through the full release cycle with PM, design, and dev.
  • Built PyTest + Appium automation in GitHub Actions for simulated and bench vehicles.
  • Expanded Android and iOS coverage and isolated regressions early.
  • Mentored junior interns on test design, debugging, and automation fundamentals.

Impact

  • Improved release confidence by increasing automated coverage across platforms.
  • Reduced coordination overhead by keeping release status and blockers visible.

Stack

Python, PyTest, Appium, GitHub Actions, Android Studio (Java/Kotlin), Xcode (Swift)

item.title: Software Team Lead @ SFU Robot Soccer
item.description:
Role: Software Team Lead
Location: Burnaby, BC
Team: SFU Autonomous Robot Soccer Club

Overview

What I shipped

  • Directed design and development of autonomous robot software in C++ using Qt6 and Protobuf.
  • Ran weekly software meetings and coordinated across sub-teams in admin syncs.
  • Led recruitment by reviewing applications, conducting interviews, and onboarding new members.
  • Collaborated with hardware teams to integrate systems and meet competition deadlines.

Impact

  • Established repeatable team processes that improved delivery cadence.
  • Strengthened cross-team alignment to ship competition-ready robots.

Stack

C++17/20, Qt6, Protobuf

item.title: Test automation & CI/CD integration @ Operto
item.description:
Role: Quality Assurance Engineer
Location: Vancouver, BC
Team: Operto Guest Technologies

Overview

Focused on building a reliable E2E suite that matched the most common user flows so feature releases could ship faster without manual regression cycles.

What I shipped

  • Authored 200 Playwright tests in TypeScript covering new features and 85% of top user flows.
  • Integrated the suite into CI/CD to provide fast feedback for engineers.
  • Led cross-team triage to align on severity and ownership.

Impact

  • Significantly reduced manual testing load and shortened release feedback loops.
  • Clearer bug ownership improved release predictability.

Stack

TypeScript, Playwright, CI/CD, FullStory

item.title: Firmware Analysis & QA Tooling @ Gatekeeper
item.description:
Role: Software Systems Engineer
Location: Abbotsford, BC
Team: Gatekeeper Systems Inc.

Overview

Built tooling to eliminate manual testing bottlenecks while also hardening the QA workflow with firmware analysis and anomaly detection.

What I shipped

  • Automated 150 manual tests by emulating HTTPS device traffic using scapy.
  • Reconstructed firmware images with binwalk and analyzed behavior with radare2 and Ghidra.
  • Prototyped user-space emulation with QEMU to validate findings.
  • Delivered a concurrent network/log anomaly tool now standard in the QA toolkit.

Impact

  • Removed the dependency on physical hardware for core regression tests.
  • Improved visibility into device behavior and potential security issues.

Stack

Python, scapy, Wireshark, tcpdump, binwalk, radare2, Ghidra, QEMU
